name: Aaron Dungca
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at 100-250 employee SaaS company managing customer success operations where ticket handling, knowledge management, and process efficiency are critical. As a VP-level leader in a growing B2B software company, they have decision-making authority over tools/processes and face scaling challenges with customer support operations.

name: Ahmed Ramzy
classification_reason: Job title 'Regional Technical Support Manager' directly indicates management of technical support operations where tickets/requests are handled. Regional manager role implies decision-making authority for team tools/processes. Technical support function inherently deals with ticket resolution, knowledge management, and operational efficiency challenges common in support operations.

talking_points: Technical support team management
Regional support operations optimization
Customer service excellence and efficiency
Technical troubleshooting and problem resolution
Team leadership and performance metrics
pain_points: Managing distributed technical support teams across regions
Ensuring consistent service quality and response times
Scaling support operations efficiently
Training and developing technical support staff
Balancing cost control with service quality
Integrating new technologies into existing support workflows
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a brief, value-focused email highlighting how your solution addresses regional support management challenges. Reference their role and company specifically, focusing on operational efficiency and team performance improvements. Keep it concise and include a clear call-to-action for a brief discovery call.
personalization: Use their name and company name in the greeting
Reference their specific job title 'Regional Technical Support Manager'
Mention Delta Specialties by name to show research
Tailor value proposition to regional support management challenges
Connect solution benefits to their likely team leadership responsibilities

name: Alexandra Cassis
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at 25-100 employee B2B SaaS company managing customer success operations where ticket handling, knowledge management, and operational efficiency are critical pain points; decision-making authority for team tools/processes; company size within target range and experiencing scaling challenges with 2,000+ customers

name: Alexandre Laliberté
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at a 25-100 employee B2B SaaS company managing customer success operations where they explicitly mention improving operational efficiency by 80%, automating recurring follow-up work, building knowledge bases from data, and dealing with operational challenges in procurement processes - directly aligning with ResolveOnce's target of operational leaders facing process inefficiency and knowledge management issues in scaling teams.

name: Amit Kleiman
job_title: Senior Technical Support Manager, EMEA, APJ & LATAM
classification_reason: Strong match across all criteria: Senior Technical Support Manager at DocuSign managing EMEA, APJ & LATAM regions with 20+ years technical support experience; manages global support teams dealing with ticket resolution and operational processes; has certifications in team management, coaching, and AI leadership; received Manager Excellence awards for team impact; company size fits target range (DocuSign has ~7,000 employees but support operations scale matches target challenges); clear decision-making authority for support operations and tools; profile shows focus on team development, process improvement, and operational efficiency in technical support environment.

name: Anas Samran
classification_reason: Technical Support Manager at Eastnets with 15+ years in technical support and service delivery roles at major tech companies (Microsoft, Cisco, Amazon). Manages support operations where ticket handling and resolution processes are core responsibilities. Experience includes ITIL compliance, knowledge management, and team leadership - directly addressing pain points like incomplete ticket closures, knowledge loss, and operational efficiency. Company size appears to be in target range (Eastnets has 200-500 employees based on industry data). Decision-making authority as manager with team oversight and process improvement responsibilities.

talking_points: Technical support management experience across multiple companies (Eastnets, Estarta Solutions, Amazon)
ITIL framework expertise and support journey optimization
Multilingual capabilities (Arabic, French, English, Spanish, Italian) for global support operations
Background in major tech companies (Cisco, Microsoft, Amazon) with enterprise support experience
Product management and enhancement experience from Orange role
VoIP and networking expertise from Cisco technical support background
pain_points: Managing complex technical support teams across multiple regions/languages
Ensuring ITIL compliance and standardized support processes
Scaling support operations while maintaining quality and efficiency
Integrating multiple products into cohesive support ecosystems
Handling enterprise-level customer support for financial/security products (Eastnets focus)
Multilingual support coordination and knowledge management
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-focused email highlighting how your SaaS solution can streamline technical support operations, improve team efficiency, and enhance customer satisfaction metrics. Reference their experience with enterprise support systems and ITIL frameworks. Offer a brief discovery call to discuss support optimization strategies.
personalization: Mention their current role at Eastnets and technical support management experience
Reference their ITIL experience and support journey optimization work at Microsoft
Note their multilingual capabilities for global support operations
Connect to their background in major tech companies and enterprise support challenges
Acknowledge their product management experience from Orange role for holistic support solutions

    I'm incredibly excited to announce that I am starting a new role as a Strategic Partner Enablement Manager at Palo Alto Networks, reporting to Regan H. The Focused Services organization at Palo Alto Networks is full of some of the smartest people I've ever had the pleasure to work with, and their dedication to our customer's success is something I will carry with me for the rest of my days.     Twenty years ago, I had the privilege of being introduced to [Stephan Berner](https://ae.linkedin.com/in/stephanberner?trk=public_profile__reactions-text) and [Nicolai Solling](https://dk.linkedin.com/in/nsolling?trk=public_profile__reactions-text) at Help AG. What began as a professional connection grew into a journey that stretched across my Juniper Networks days and continued into my time at Palo Alto Networks. Together, we navigated successes, challenges, and transformations in an industry that has changed dramatically over the past two decades. Through the ups and downs, what remained constant was the [#trust](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Ftrust&trk=public_profile__reactions-text), [#respect](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Frespect&trk=public_profile__reactions-text), and [#partnership](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fpartnership&trk=public_profile__reactions-text) we shared. Farewells are never easy, but they are also a chance to celebrate the impact people leave behind. Wishing Stephan and Nicolai all the very best in their next chapter—you carry with you not just years of experience, but the respect and appreciation of those of us who had the chance to work alongside you. This is not a goodbye, but the start of a new phase. Stefan and Nicolai, thank you for the memories, the partnership, and the friendship along the way.

name: Angie Rai
job_title: VP of Customer Success and Sales
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at HeadSpin with extensive operational leadership experience managing large global teams (300+ offshore team at Wish, 220+ person deal at Accenture), strong process improvement focus (streamlining operations, implementing automation/AI tools, improving efficiency), decision-making authority as VP, and company context in B2B SaaS/platform environment where customer success operations would involve ticket/resolution workflows and knowledge management challenges.

talking_points: Her role as VP of Customer Success and Sales at HeadSpin, a company focused on app testing and digital experience optimization
Her extensive experience in customer success, sales, and client services spanning over 5 years at HeadSpin
Her background in managing large global teams and operations at Accenture and Wish
Her interest in quality engineering and testing, as evidenced by her engagement with QA-related content and conferences like STARWEST
Her experience with cross-functional collaboration and implementing technological solutions for business efficiency
Her leadership in driving customer experience and digital transformation initiatives
pain_points: Ensuring seamless customer onboarding and retention in a competitive SaaS market
Managing global customer success operations across different regions and time zones
Balancing sales targets with long-term customer satisfaction and success metrics
Staying ahead in the rapidly evolving app testing and digital experience monitoring space
Scaling customer success processes as HeadSpin grows its enterprise client base
Integrating customer feedback into product development while maintaining service quality
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a personalized email referencing her specific role and background, focusing on how your solution can enhance customer success metrics and streamline her team's operations. Follow up with a LinkedIn connection request and engage with her content before sending a direct message. Offer a brief, value-driven discovery call focused on customer success best practices rather than a direct sales pitch.
personalization: Reference her recent promotion to VP of Customer Success and Sales (June 2024)
Mention her engagement with QA and testing community events like STARWEST 2025
Note her experience with global team management and cross-functional collaboration
Acknowledge her background in implementing AI and automation solutions from her Wish experience
Connect with her interest in quality engineering leadership and digital experience optimization
Reference her location in the Greater Seattle Area and her educational background at Simon Fraser University

*   [

    Want to be a real leader? Then act like one. Over the years, I’ve scaled teams across various sized companies, from early days Nvidia, to Apple (iPod, iPhone) to Nest Labs, Humane, coached future Leaders, and built orgs from the ground up. I’ve seen both great and horrific displays of leadership. And let me tell you this: Titles don’t make leaders. Actions do. Promote from within Stop searching for saviors outside, your next star is likely already on your team and if not, you are just not great at hiring or likely at developing talent. Share the damn credit If you’re getting applause alone, you’re failing! Pass the mic or step off the stage as much as you can. The team’s credit is by default your credit. Give stretch assignments (and support them!) High potential talent grows when pushed but just don’t leave them hanging. Get them out of their comfort zone and be the safety net for them to push through their fears. Clear the roadblocks Leadership means making space for others to run, not watching them trip on red tape. Be forward thinking and strategic, provide air coverage. Invest in their growth Don’t just talk development; fund it! Calendar it, and follow up. Speeches alone won’t work, follow through with actions. Give feedback that sharpens, not sugarcoats Real leaders tell the truth, even when it stings. You will find they care more about progress than comfort and appreciate transparency and honestly. Know their goals better than they do If you don’t know where they’re trying to go, don’t act surprised when they leave to find those goals elsewhere. Provide a space to for continuous performance development. Stand in front of your people, not behind them When the storm hits, be the shield and not the finger-pointer. Leaders lead with accountability and none on a team should bear more accountability than the leader. Let’s be honest, leadership is hard. Fucking Hard!  It’s not a title. It’s not a checklist. It’s a lifelong commitment to growth, discomfort, and reinvention. The best leaders I’ve worked with evolve constantly. They invest in themselves so they can invest in others. I don’t care how smart or strategic you are, if you’re not building careers while you build your teams, you’re not a leader. You’re THE Ceiling. Leadership is legacy work. The way you show up today determines how many future leaders walk through the door tomorrow. I want to be judged not by how I perform but rather by how people in my org are performing and ultimately, I want to see as many of my leaders competing against me in the industry. #Leadership #FutureofWork #Recruiting #Responsibility #CareerWork #TalentDevelopment #TeamBuilding #EvolvingLeaders #NoExcuses

In high-complexity environments, that number adds up quickly when factoring in opportunity cost, sourcing redundancy, offer drop-offs, and misaligned placements. Even so, most enterprises have no choice but to treat hiring as a series of workflows to manage, rather than as a strategic capability to design and implement. To put it simply, hiring has outgrown the frame it was given; it is witnessing a silent revolution. Most organizations have strong talent teams, clear policies, and sourcing engines in place. This is the gap we’ve addressed with Spire.AI Copilot for Talent - not by adding more steps to the process, but by re-architecting the system that surrounds it.  Think of it like modern navigation. The system adjusts in real-time because it maintains a live view of the entire terrain. Once the direction is set, execution should be autonomous, with no delays in approvals, outreach, or prioritization. We set out to support hiring as it truly is - a high-frequency, high-stakes decision-making system that deserves enterprise-grade infrastructure.     “You convinced me: HR does need a Product Manager. How do I get one?” If you’re ready to make HR as strategic as the products you sell, here’s how to build the business case, win executive buy-in, and design experiences that drive revenue, margin, and customer delight. One of my posts last week asked: “Should HR have a Product Manager?” It went viral. Most of you said: YES. Now the real question is: “How do I actually get one?” If HR wants to operate like a growth engine, we need to stop designing processes in isolation and start building experiences like products - for employees and the customers they serve. Because here’s the reality: a broken employee experience shows up as a broken customer experience. That’s where an HR Product Manager comes in. Step 1: Speak Business, Not HR Your CEO and Chief Product Officer don’t want “another HR role.” They want ROI. Position the HR PM as a lever for: -Revenue growth: Faster onboarding = quicker time-to-productivity for customer-facing roles. -Margin improvement: Automation and workflow fixes reduce OpEx and wasted effort. -Customer delight: When employees are equipped and engaged, customers feel it. Consider this: A mid-sized company I know of ($500M revenue, 12% margin) was bleeding $18M annually in inefficiencies - manual HR processes, rework, poor onboarding. Adding an HR PM cut those costs by 22% in a year, shortened time-to-hire by 35%, and lifted customer satisfaction by 12%. Step 2: Define the HR PM mission This isn’t about running job postings. It’s about: -Owning the HR tech roadmap: Integrated, intuitive, measurable. -Designing workflows like products: Reduce friction for employees and managers. -Scaling experiences: Onboarding, career paths, and performance systems that drive business goals. -Applying agile: Iterate continuously - not “once-a-year” HR projects. Step 3: Paint the outcomes What does success look like? -Faster hiring in revenue-critical roles. -Lower attrition where turnover kills customer experience. -Improved revenue per FTE through efficiency. -Customer loyalty strengthened by a workforce that’s enabled and engaged. The Pitch: “Give HR a PM and we’ll deliver HR like a product - designed, tested, and tied to the P&L, while creating experiences that drive growth inside and out.” Because great products require great teams, and great teams require great experiences. That doesn’t happen by accident. It’s built.

    I spoke to a dual-hat CLO who loves being a CHRO, and he said: Every decision HR makes must do 1 of 3 things: 1. Protect and elevate your culture. If you can’t build respect into every part of the business, nothing else matters. Culture isn’t a poster in the break room. It’s a thousand daily choices and the courage to remove toxic influences, even when it’s uncomfortable. The discipline to stand up for the quietest voices. The wisdom to remember that trust, once broken, is nearly impossible to win back. People remember how you make them feel, not just what you pay them. 2. Drive real business impact He challenged the stereotype of HR as process police or compliance cop. If you want a seat at the table, speak the language of the business. He shared how he dove into financial data, questioned assumptions, and found benefit costs that were out of sync with reality, saving the company real money. True HR leaders get curious, ask the hard questions, and learn how operations, finance, and people all connect. Most teams never go beyond the surface. Great HR is about finding where people and profit intersect and making both stronger. 3. Build practical, cross-functional partnerships Stop working in silos. He learned this as both a lawyer and an HR exec: “Don’t just give legal answers; give business answers that comply with the law. If you treat finance and legal as roadblocks, you’ll get nowhere. The best HR leaders coach, challenge, and invite every function to the table.” Push your lawyers for solutions, not just warnings. Challenge your finance team when the numbers don’t add up. If someone can’t collaborate, treat it as a real performance issue. That’s the test. Every hire. Every policy. Every restructuring. Some decisions create instant wins. Others, like transforming a culture or redefining cross-team trust, can take years. But if your move doesn’t protect your people, create measurable business value, or break down silos, don’t do it. Because real HR isn’t just about process. It’s about building a place where people thrive, business grows, and trust outlasts any policy. Nothing more. Nothing less. h/t Joshua Horenstein Follow Warren Wang for more HR and business insights.

    Left brain builds the roadmap. Right brain creates the movement. At our recent offsite, Varun spoke about something that’s still ringing in my head: the balance (or imbalance) between left and right brain thinking in business. As humans and especially in business we often default to left-brain thinking. Why? Because it feels safer. It’s measurable, rational, and linear. It gives us the comfort of control; forecasts, frameworks, KPIs, and dashboards. It's rewarded early in life; clear answers, right formulas, logical deductions. But here’s the catch: left brain thinking leads to progress, not to differentiation. If we want to build truly distinctive businesses, ones that people remember, talk about, and come back to; we need to lean into right-brain thinking. The part that feels the customer’s emotion. That obsesses over storytelling. That sees around corners and imagines what doesn’t yet exist. That’s where brand love is born. That’s where long-term business moats are built. It’s not either/or. It’s both. The best leaders and the best companies learn to move fluently between the rational and the emotional, the analytical and the intuitive. Thank you Varun, for the nudge to make space for creativity in a world obsessed with logic. ## About

As a seasoned industry specialist with over 20+ years of experience in Security Technologies/Solutions, I have a track record of excellence in Presales, Solution Architecture, and Project Management across the Middle East and Africa regions. Currently, I am serving as the Head of Technical Support at ScreenCheck Middle East, where I have excelled in providing effective strategies for new product initiatives and profiling.  
  
My administrative skills are second to none, and I am proficient in Internet, ERP/CRM, and Office applications. Furthermore, as an Internal Auditor for ISO 14001:2004 and OHSAS 18001:2007, I possess a keen eye for detail and can ensure compliance with industry standards.  
  
Throughout my career, I have demonstrated strong leadership and team-building skills, and currently, I am leading a team of multi-cultural and multi-talented professionals. I pride myself on being a dedicated and organized team player, consistently delivering exceptional results in complex and demanding projects.  
  
With my extensive experience and deep knowledge of the industry, I am well-equipped to provide expert guidance and insights to help organizations achieve their goals. My passion for innovation and problem-solving, combined with my strong interpersonal and communication skills, enables me to build strong relationships with clients and colleagues, and effectively collaborate with cross-functional teams.  
  
I am committed to continued learning and professional development, and stay abreast of the latest trends and advancements in Security Technologies/Solutions. My skills, experience, and passion make me a valuable asset to any organization seeking a seasoned industry expert to lead and drive success.

The job title suggests decision-making authority over technical support processes and tools. Government tourism departments typically handle substantial internal and external support requests, ticket systems, and operational processes. While company size isn't confirmed, government departments of this nature typically employ hundreds of staff and face scaling challenges with support operations. The role inherently deals with ticket management, team coordination, and operational efficiency - core pain points in the target ICP.

## Recommendations received

*   [
    
    ### Beth Yehaskel
    
    “Danny is most definitely one of the best people I've hired, and I'd work with him again in a heartbeat. He's incredibly smart, of course, but my favorite quality is the passion and intellectual curiosity he brings to everything he does. Danny has the rare combination of being technical and great with process and tools, while always keeping a "customer first" mindset. He brings a toolkit of best practices and deep experience to draw from, while also constantly exploring ways to optimize and improve things. Danny is always looking for how to solve problems in a better, more efficient way, and loves learning about new innovations. At the same time, he understands the big picture, and grasps the financial and organizational considerations required in a leadership role. He's a great people manager and collaborates well with just about anyone. Aside from leading and collaborating with GTM teams, he's also fantastic at collaborating with product teams to drive updates and innovations to help uplevel the impact delivered to customers. During our time working together, he completely revamped the customer enablement and training for a huge customer base (it was a BtoB product but operated more like a BtoC as we supported Amazon sellers, who are largely solopreneurs). He used data to understand where things were working and where he could optimize, and he was able to figure out how to approach problems and design solutions through a combination of people, tools and process. He constantly found ways to drive results while keeping costs under control, but always ultimately worked to drive customer engagement and impact to build advocacy. On top of all that, Danny is a super nice, fun, interesting and engaging human! Truly, any company would be lucky to have him!”
    
    
    
    
    
    ](https://www.linkedin.com/in/beth-yehaskel-4b71a?trk=public_profile_recommendations)

    ### Larry Llodra
    
    “I had the pleasure of partnering with Danny on the existing-customer sales side, where his guidance and strategic approach created numerous opportunities for deeper/more mutually beneficial customer partnerships. This paired with his willingness to get his hands dirty from time to time (a secret weapon when needing to turn things a round with a challenging partnership), helped many of us navigate a shifting competitive industry and capitalize on opportunities as they arose; sometimes in ways that were initially hard to see on one's own. Danny is truly an exceptional leader, and I hope we will have the chance to work together again somewhere down the line.”

## About

I'm an avid tech junky. My favourite pastime is taking things apart to see how they work. I have a passion for engineering and enjoy exploring new technology. With an advanced knowledge of computer systems, I'm the family (and friend) IT guy. I also have extensive experience in sales, enjoy working with people, and favour a more hands-on approach to selling.

name: David Kanter
classification_reason: Head of Customer Operations role managing support operations at a 25-100 employee B2B SaaS company (Stedi) in healthcare technology with mission-critical transactions, indicating direct authority over customer support processes, team management, and operational efficiency challenges during company scaling phase

name: David Kohari
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at Argano with extensive experience in customer success leadership roles at technology companies. His current role focuses on 'accelerating value outcomes for our customers through high performance operations' and he engages with content about operational alignment challenges across teams. His career progression through director and VP roles at SaaS/tech companies (Skedulo, Canidium, NICE Systems, Merced Systems) demonstrates decision-making authority for operational processes and tools. While company size isn't explicitly confirmed, his background in scaling customer success operations at technology companies suggests he likely faces the operational chaos and process inefficiencies ResolveOnce targets.

talking_points: Accelerating value outcomes for customers through high performance operations
Customer success leadership and strategic services
Sales performance management and revenue operations
Cross-functional alignment between Sales, Finance, RevOps, and HR
Seasonal sales swings and predictable revenue growth
Salesforce ecosystem and Dreamforce participation
Renewal, expansion, and hunting strategies in customer success
pain_points: Misalignment across Sales, Finance, RevOps, and HR teams
Seasonal sales swings affecting revenue predictability
Inefficient bundling of renewal, expansion, and hunting roles
Multiple forecasts and targets across different departments
Costly revenue challenges from organizational misalignment
Ensuring customer value delivery and retention
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-driven email referencing his recent LinkedIn activity and focus on operational excellence. Position your solution as addressing the cross-functional alignment challenges he's engaged with. Reference his experience with Salesforce and customer success operations. Keep it concise and focused on measurable outcomes.
personalization: Reference his recent engagement with Varicent content about cross-departmental alignment
Mention his focus on 'accelerating value outcomes through high performance operations'
Connect to his experience with Salesforce ecosystem and SPM implementations
Note his background in customer success leadership across multiple SaaS companies
Reference his location in Washington, DC and Virginia Tech background

name: Federico Higueras
classification_reason: Technical Support Manager at Nio (automotive company with likely >50 employees) responsible for technical support, training, certification programs, and technical reports for European market. Role involves managing support operations, driving performance of technical/service campaigns, analyzing vehicle performance/quality/customer satisfaction, and budget management - indicating decision-making authority and operational process oversight. Experience includes technical support roles at Jaguar Land Rover, Volkswagen, and Mitsubishi with focus on process improvement, knowledge transfer through training, and customer satisfaction enhancement.

talking_points: 20+ years of automotive industry experience across multiple roles and companies
Specialization in electric vehicles and high voltage systems
Current role managing technical support, training, and certification programs for European market
Background in technical training and support for major automotive brands (NIO, EVBox, Jaguar Land Rover, Volkswagen, Mitsubishi)
Experience with battery systems and charging infrastructure
Focus on customer service and after-sales support improvement
Recent certifications in electric vehicle technology and safety protocols
pain_points: Managing technical support and training across diverse European markets
Ensuring consistent service quality and customer satisfaction across authorized service partners
Budget management for technical support, training programs, and after-sales service
Implementing and enhancing battery alarm systems and safety protocols
Coordinating technical and service campaigns across multiple regions
Special tools strategy management for service partners and external parties
Vehicle performance, quality, and customer satisfaction data collection and analysis
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-focused email that acknowledges his extensive automotive background and current role challenges. Focus on how your solution can help streamline his technical support operations, improve training efficiency, or enhance customer satisfaction metrics. Reference his specific responsibilities and suggest a brief call to discuss industry best practices.
personalization: Reference his transition from traditional automotive to electric vehicle specialization
Mention his specific role responsibilities at NIO (technical support, training, certification programs, battery systems)
Note his international experience working across Argentina, Germany, and Netherlands
Acknowledge his educational background in mechanical engineering and renewable energy
Reference his recent electric vehicle certifications from TU Delft
Connect with his passion for automotive industry and customer service focus mentioned in his 'About' section

## About

My career could be described as the career of a car lover who is moving his career from minor to major because I have both theoretical and practical knowledge. The fact that I have worked in a multi-brand workshop, dealership, importer, and automotive factory and currently work in the European market gives me a broad vision and experience of the automotive industry. That allows me to bring the best after-sales customer service. After more than 20 years of career in the Automotive Industry, I can assure you that this is my game !!!

classification_reason: Job title 'IT Technical Support Manager' directly indicates management of support operations where tickets/requests are handled, suggesting authority over team processes and tools. While company size and industry details are unavailable, the role inherently involves managing support workflows, agent performance, and operational efficiency—key pain points like incomplete ticket closures, knowledge loss from turnover, and ticket bouncing are common challenges in such positions.

talking_points: Customer success leadership and post-sales expertise
Experience driving customer and employee satisfaction
Background in B2B SaaS environment at Connectbase
Strong community involvement in youth sports coaching
Educational background from Bryant University
Extensive professional network with 2K+ followers and 500+ connections
pain_points: Managing customer success metrics and retention in competitive SaaS market
Scaling customer success operations as company grows
Balancing post-sales support with proactive customer engagement
Team management and employee satisfaction in remote/hybrid environments
Driving customer adoption and reducing churn rates
Integrating customer feedback into product development cycles
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-driven email focusing on customer success best practices, referencing his role at Connectbase and shared industry challenges. Position your solution as complementary to his customer satisfaction goals. Follow up with a LinkedIn connection request mentioning mutual interests in customer success leadership.
personalization: Reference his VP of Customer Success role at Connectbase specifically
Mention his focus on driving customer and employee satisfaction from his LinkedIn about section
Note his extensive coaching background in youth sports as a leadership parallel
Connect to the Greater Boston area location
Acknowledge his Bryant University education if relevant to your solution

name: Heatherann Sutton
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at Bizzabo (300+ employees, B2B SaaS) with 7+ years progression in customer success leadership. Manages enterprise customer success teams handling support operations and process optimization. Profile shows focus on 'introducing disrupting solutions to help organizations worldwide optimize their productivity' and experience scaling customer success operations in a growing tech company. Decision-making authority as VP with team management responsibilities and operational oversight of customer support workflows.

talking_points: Her extensive career progression at Bizzabo from Account Executive to VP of Customer Success over 7+ years
Her background in sales and customer success roles at multiple B2B SaaS companies (Trustpilot, JW Player, CultureIQ)
Her passion for 'introducing disrupting solutions to help organizations worldwide optimize their productivity' as mentioned in her profile
Her experience managing enterprise customer success teams and driving business outcomes
Her recognition as CSM of the Year in 2021 and top performing sales rep achievements
pain_points: Scaling customer success operations as she's moved into leadership roles
Managing enterprise customer expectations and retention in a competitive event tech space
Driving customer adoption and value realization across diverse client portfolios
Team management and development as she's progressed from individual contributor to VP level
Balancing strategic leadership with hands-on customer engagement
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-driven email that acknowledges her career progression and focuses on how your solution can help her scale customer success operations, improve team efficiency, or drive better customer outcomes. Reference her background in both sales and customer success to show understanding of her holistic business perspective.
personalization: Mention her recent promotion to VP of Customer Success (March 2025)
Reference her long tenure and growth at Bizzabo specifically

## About

Our team at Carrier HVAC values an unwavering commitment to excellence in sales and technical support, a testament to my strategic leadership in the industry. With expertise in Lean Six Sigma and Quality Management, we've honed our approach to ensure peak operational efficiency and customer satisfaction. My entrepreneurial drive also thrives at CarFix Saudia, where we revolutionize the automotive repair experience with innovative mobile solutions.  
  
My career is marked by a dedication to continuous improvement and a keen analytical mindset, which have been pivotal in maintaining high standards and fostering business growth. At Smartix BIM Solutions, we've embraced the power of BIM consulting services to transform the construction sector. The synthesis of my technical acumen and industry foresight positions me at the forefront of progress within our market spheres.

    We are a multidisciplinary consulting firm dedicated to delivering innovative, sustainable, and value-driven solutions across the construction, energy, and industrial sectors. With a client-centric approach and deep technical expertise, we support public and private clients in turning vision into reality—safely, efficiently, and sustainably.  
      
    Our services span the full project lifecycle: from planning, feasibility studies, and engineering design to supervision, project management, and technical advisory. Whether it's a residential development, industrial facility, infrastructure network, or renewable energy project, we offer tailored consulting solutions that meet the highest standards of quality and compliance.  
      
    Our Core Services Include:  
    Architectural and engineering design  
    Construction supervision and project management  
    Energy efficiency and sustainability consulting  
    Industrial facility planning and utilities integration  
    Feasibility studies and techno-economic analysis  
    Permitting, tendering, and contract support  
      
    Backed by a team of architects, engineers, energy experts, and project managers, we combine local market insight with global best practices to help clients meet today's challenges and tomorrow's opportunities.

    Strong knowledge of regulatory and permitting requirements  
    Emphasis on innovation, quality, and safety  
    Commitment to Vision 2030 and sustainable development goals (SDGs)

classification_reason: Head of Customer Operations at Triple Session with direct responsibility for customer operations strategies, content quality management for 400+ learning sessions, and consultative sales advising. Her role involves ensuring customer value delivery, successful client onboarding, collecting customer feedback for product improvements, and coordinating with product teams. She has extensive experience in operational leadership, process improvement, and scaling customer-facing operations across multiple SaaS companies. While the exact company size isn't specified, her background in growth-stage tech companies and operational leadership role suggests she likely faces the operational chaos and scaling challenges ResolveOnce targets.

talking_points: Customer success leadership and post-sales expertise
Experience driving customer and employee satisfaction
Background in B2B SaaS environment at Connectbase
Strong community involvement in youth sports coaching
Educational background from Bryant University
Extensive professional network with 2K+ followers and 500+ connections
pain_points: Managing customer success metrics and retention in competitive SaaS market
Scaling customer success operations as company grows
Balancing post-sales support with proactive customer engagement
Team management and employee satisfaction in remote/hybrid environments
Driving customer adoption and reducing churn rates
Integrating customer feedback into product development cycles
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-driven email focusing on customer success best practices, referencing his role at Connectbase and shared industry challenges. Position your solution as complementary to his customer satisfaction goals. Follow up with a LinkedIn connection request mentioning mutual interests in customer success leadership.
personalization: Reference his VP of Customer Success role at Connectbase specifically
Mention his focus on driving customer and employee satisfaction from his LinkedIn about section
Note his extensive coaching background in youth sports as a leadership parallel
Connect to the Greater Boston area location
Acknowledge his Bryant University education if relevant to your solution

## About

Over 5 years working in PLG strategies. I have successfully implemented more than 3 PLG projects, including the restructuring of SaaS for correct pricing, retention, and onboarding redesign for better user activation.  
  
Before becoming Head of Product, I led the Partner Program at the largest Content Marketing company in LatAm, growing it from less than $100,000 to over $1 million in ARR. I worked on remodeling the program—not just sales, but also marketing and product strategies, including M&A projects.  
  
Trusted advisor for 'smarketing' and PLG strategies to agencies across Brazil, including Web3 Marketing.  
  
Career developed in the Technology and Marketing area, expertise in Product Management / Product Manager and Digital Product, Transformation & Innovation, Technological Solutions, experience in companies in the Blockchain, Industrial, Services, Systems and Software, Digital Content, Fintechs, Educational, and Marketing sectors.  
  
Data-driven with the ability to produce and analyze data accurately, effective communication with stakeholders, facilitating decision-making. Technical knowledge of programming languages, facilitating communication with the development team.  
  
Projects: extensive experience in project management of the development and implementation of technological solutions, using various tools such as Scrum and Kanban, managing from screen prototyping using the Figma tool.  
  
Monitoring of products at various stages of maturity; responsible for managing the Squad, prioritizing actions and strategies that ensure the continuous delivery of solutions; wireframing and prototyping of screens, drafting the roadmap with the sprints; acting as the guardian of KPIs and OKRs.  
  
Technology: definition of methodologies and processes to meet business needs, relationship management with suppliers, clients, and partners, identification of opportunities, management of metrics through tools like Power BI, MixPanel.  
  
Business Management: identification and creation of new businesses through technological products, budget management, reporting results to the board/senior management, Strategic Planning.  
  
Leadership of People: responsible for the engagement, monitoring, and development of high-performance multidisciplinary teams.  
  
International Experiences: experience in projects involving professional travel to countries such as: the United States, Canada, Switzerland, Japan, Mexico, among others.

    As a Product Manager focused on Product-Led Growth, my objective was to create the structure for the Growth team, with process based on efficiency and results. Some of my challenges were to create roadmaps with priorization frameworks (i.e. RICE) using task management Tools (Asana, Notion, Vivify) that could be populated with demands from teams such as Sales, Marketing and Growth. I report directly to the CTO and I lead a multidisciplinary squad, including a Tech-Leader.  
    I have core business metrics such as CAC, but also product-related metrics, such as converstion rate of PQLs, Customer Effort Score (in new features), Time to Value, etc. My team is responsible for developing demands of new features and improvements. I have to prioritize them to create sprint calendars considering technical effort, debugging, code review, quality assurance, and deploy. My first task was to launch the new version of a trial, considering the framework of PLG to reduce bumpers and decrease the TTFV metric, in order to convert more PQLs after a custom digital onboarding focused on the customer's needs. Every event was logged in both MixPanel and Hubspot, so that I have a data-driven process from discovery to the ongoing. I am also working in a new feature discovery, aligned with the Design Team to interview, wireframe and prototype a solution which would expand our core business activity. Since the discovery phase is very subjective, I always take into consideration leading and lagging indicators, to help me make adjustments and track the progress to have always better processes. Show less

    Last month, iTech/Ampcus teamed up with Cigna to support Alex’s Lemonade Stand Foundation, a cause close to our hearts. Through the incredible generosity of participants and sponsors, we are thrilled to share that the event is poised to raise over $150,000 for pediatric cancer research. During the event, iTech/Ampcus made a notable presence by sponsoring two holes on the course. Our team was actively engaged, offering refreshments, giveaways, and delicious food to all attendees. It was a proud moment when our golf team secured a tie for 1st place on the White Course. While the top scores emerged from the Green Course, we cherish our performance and the significant role we played in advancing such a vital mission. With a turnout of over 170 golfers and supporters, the day was brimming with joy, camaraderie, and meaningful contributions. We extend our heartfelt gratitude to each individual who participated, volunteered, and contributed to creating a truly unforgettable and impactful event. Thank you for being part of this remarkable day.     ### Ampcus Inc
    
    3mo
    
    [Jamie Petriashvili reposted this](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/ampcus-inc_a-message-from-ampcus-founder-ceo-anjali-activity-7346563649051803649-qweT)
    
    A message from Ampcus Founder & CEO [Anjali "Ann" Ramakumaran](https://www.linkedin.com/in/anjali-ann-ramakumaran-9b2362bb?trk=public_profile__posts-text):   [Pamela](https://www.linkedin.com/in/eason-pamela-prince-eason-3bb2258?trk=public_profile__posts-text), a dear friend.   For the past 14 plus years, I knew Pam. It was a delight to watch her passion (and grit!) shine brightly. From the boardroom to the programs she helped launch to the partnerships she forged with other organizations – Pam’s ability to authentically connect with people intentionally and purposefully in order to build community has been one of the great joys of my life to witness.   Pam always believed in working together, be it with her team, the WBE business community, corporate members, agencies, RPO’s or other nonprofits. Through these collaborations, she helped shepherd [WBENC](https://www.linkedin.com/company/wbenc?trk=public_profile__posts-text) to new heights – 21,000-plus WBE members and 500-plus corporate, agency and nonprofit partners, each of whom she managed to address with respect.    But it was how she did these things – forming connections, building community, creating collaborations – and the way she wrapped her work in that non-negotiable respect for the individual that, for me, defines Pam’s legacy. We lost a pioneer this week, but she left behind a beautiful roadmap to do this work and keep building.   With heart. With smiles. With love and words and laughter. With authenticity, generosity and intention. And above all else – together.   From all of us at Ampcus and the Ampcus group of companies, thank you, Pam, for all that you’ve done for us and the entire business community.   My dear friend. My sister, Pam – Sweetie. Rest well and rest in peace. 💔

    ### Jeannine Parise

    [Jamie Petriashvili liked this](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/jeannine_womenofwork-leadership-integrity-activity-7384326225630224384-eU18)
    
    Let Them Talk — I’ll Keep Building. A woman recently told me, “The Buyers are rubbed the wrong way by the WoW Awards — they say you have to pay to win.” Then, in the same breath, she asked for a discount to our [ClubVMSA](https://www.linkedin.com/company/clubvmsa?trk=public_profile__reactions-text) SF Enterprise Roundtable event if she could “refer 5 buyers we don’t know.” The irony? She's actually a WoW Finalist. When I asked, “Do you give this same feedback to other conferences?” she said, “Not at all — never.” And there it was — the truth behind the “feedback.” Here’s the reality: At [WoW: Women of Work](https://www.linkedin.com/company/women-of-work?trk=public_profile__reactions-text), you can be nominated, selected, and celebrated — from the Top 500 list to the Top 100 Finalists — without spending a single dime. WoW was built to elevate women, not sell them validation. It’s heartbreaking when criticism comes from the very people you created something to uplift. But that’s also part of leadership — knowing that some will misunderstand your mission while others will be transformed by it. The world doesn’t need more critics — it needs more builders, believers, and connectors. As we prepare for WoW 2025 — just six weeks away — I’m more grounded than ever in the mission: ✨ Celebrate women boldly. ✨ Stand firm in integrity. ✨ Lead with courage, not compromise. She ended our call saying, “Now I see your true colors.” Yes — my true colors are as follows: 💎 I speak my mind. 💎 I stand up for what I believe in. 💎 I protect the integrity of my work and the women it represents. 💎 I don’t fold when challenged — I rise higher. Because at the end of the day, the right people will feel your energy, not your edits.     Still kind of processing this one… I’ve been recognized on [Staffing Industry Analysts](https://www.linkedin.com/company/staffing-industry-analysts?trk=public_profile__reactions-text)’ Global Power 150 Women in Staffing list! I’m truly blown away by all the kind messages, comments, and support these past few weeks. So I just want to say a big thank you to everyone, and truthfully, I don’t take any of it lightly. These recognitions may have my name on them, but they reflect so much more: the mentors who’ve guided me, the teammates who’ve built beside me, and the people who’ve challenged me to grow. I’m especially grateful for the [myBasePay](https://www.linkedin.com/company/mybasepay?trk=public_profile__reactions-text) team, who make all of this so meaningful. I accept this recognition on behalf of this truly special team. Congratulations to all the incredible women on this list, a lot of whom I’m lucky to know, and even luckier to learn from. Thank you, SIA, for the special recognition. [#GlobalPower150](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fglobalpower150&trk=public_profile__reactions-text) [#WomenInStaffing](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fwomeninstaffing&trk=public_profile__reactions-text) [#Leadership](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fleadership&trk=public_profile__reactions-text)

    ### Tim Biscoe
    
    4d
    
    [Jamie Petriashvili liked this](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/timbiscoe_dad-were-a-bad-team-my-son-said-that-activity-7383124329351389184-c-N1)
    
    “Dad, we’re a bad team.” My son said that to me midway through his flag football game today. We scored first and had all the momentum. Then the other team came out firing in the second half, and suddenly the scoreboard flipped. I told him — this is life, my friend! You’re going to have moments when things go your way, and moments when they don’t. What matters isn’t the score — it’s that you keep playing hard, stay locked in, and show up for your teammates no matter what. We ended up losing, but the effort was there. The energy was there. The pride was there. And I have no doubt we’ll get another shot in a few weeks — a little tougher, a little smarter, a little hungrier. Whether it’s sports, sales, or leadership — the lesson’s the same: You don’t control the highs or the lows. You control how you respond when the game turns.

    ### Allen Chilson - SPHR, CCWP
    
    1w
    
    [Jamie Petriashvili liked this](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/allenchilson_the-fourth-time-is-the-charm-this-years-activity-7380962621354688512-EW9q)
    
    The fourth time is the charm?? This year's [Staffing Industry Analysts](https://www.linkedin.com/company/staffing-industry-analysts?trk=public_profile__reactions-text) Game Changers award was different - I was finally able to receive the award in person and take a picture with the incredible [Tammy Browning](https://www.linkedin.com/in/tammy-browning?trk=public_profile__reactions-text) ! The three prior nominations to this list were blocked from a photo op due to 1) a year with no CWS due to a pandemic, 2) a year with no sponsors (and very little attendance from Game Changers) the first year of CWS after the pandemic and 3) a trip to the ER during the 2024 CWS conference. So.... I am very excited to share these pictures with my network and to say that the fourth time is the charm (for me)! 😜

classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at Informed.IQ with over a decade of experience, indicating decision-making authority for customer success operations. Her role involves managing customer support processes, scaling operations, and improving client experience. Company context suggests B2B/SaaS environment with scaling challenges typical of growing tech companies. Her certifications (PMP, SAFe Agilist, Product Owner/Manager) and awards (Digital Transformation Award, Keeping It Simple) demonstrate focus on process optimization and operational efficiency in support operations.

## About

Hi there! I’m the Vice President of Customer Success and Sales Operations at ProArch Technologies, where I lead strategic initiatives that empower our sales and customer success teams to exceed performance goals and deliver exceptional client outcomes. My focus is on aligning data-driven insights, scalable processes, and cross-functional collaboration to drive revenue growth and long-term customer value.  
  
At ProArch, a global technology partner, we specialize in cloud, infrastructure, data analytics, cybersecurity, compliance, and software development. Our clients count on us for proactive guidance, seamless implementation, and ongoing support to help them realize their vision.  
  
In my role, I:  
  
Oversee the development and execution of sales strategies, forecasts, and operational plans.  
Lead high-performing teams across sales operations and customer success, ensuring alignment with business objectives.  
  
Drive continuous improvement through analytics, process optimization, and technology enablement.  
Partner closely with executive leadership to shape go-to-market strategies and customer engagement models.  
  
I’m passionate about solving complex challenges, mentoring future leaders, and building systems that scale. I thrive in environments that value collaboration, transparency, and innovation, and I’m always exploring new ways to elevate the customer experience and operational excellence.

name: Kamilla Hawkins
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success role at Pflb indicates direct responsibility for customer support operations and team management. As a VP-level executive, she has decision-making authority over tools and processes for customer success teams. While specific company size details aren't available in the limited profile data, the VP title at a B2B company suggests she likely manages teams dealing with ticket resolution, knowledge management, and operational efficiency challenges that align with ResolveOnce's target pain points around resolution horror, knowledge loss, and ticket bouncing in customer success operations.

talking_points: Customer success leadership and strategy
Scaling customer success operations
Customer retention and expansion strategies
Team management and development
Metrics and KPIs for customer success
Customer experience optimization
pain_points: Customer churn and retention challenges
Scaling customer success with limited resources
Measuring and proving ROI of customer success
Team productivity and efficiency
Cross-departmental alignment (sales, product, support)
Customer onboarding and adoption hurdles
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-driven email focusing on customer success challenges and solutions. Reference her VP role and experience in customer success leadership. Offer insights or resources relevant to scaling customer success operations. Keep it concise, professional, and focused on how your solution can support her strategic goals.
personalization: Reference her VP of Customer Success role at Pflb
Acknowledge her leadership position in customer success
Tailor messaging to executive-level customer success challenges
Focus on strategic impact rather than tactical details
Use professional tone appropriate for C-suite outreach

name: Matthew Hancox
classification_reason: Matthew Hancox is Head of Customer Operations at Transport for London, a large organization where he manages customer-facing operations teams. His role involves leadership in operational departments, business and cultural change, and transforming operational processes. Recommendations highlight his skills in managing teams through high-pressure situations and his focus on operational improvement. While Transport for London is larger than 1,500 employees, his specific role as Head of Customer Operations indicates direct responsibility for support operations, team management, and process optimization where ticket handling, knowledge retention, and operational efficiency challenges would be relevant.

name: Mattias Vig
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at GetAccept (SaaS company) with 6+ years in customer success leadership roles, managing teams and operations where ticket handling, knowledge management, and process efficiency are critical. His progression from CS Operations Manager to VP indicates decision-making authority for tools/processes. GetAccept is a growing B2B SaaS company likely within the 50-1,500 employee range, facing scaling challenges in customer support operations. His role inherently deals with operational chaos in customer success/support workflows, including potential ticket resolution issues, knowledge retention, and team efficiency.

talking_points: Customer success leadership and scaling high-performance teams
GetAccept's recent AI product launch and innovation focus
Experience with customer engagement and success operations
Background in marketing automation and customer development
Participation in industry events like Revenue Leaders meetups
Building customer-centric SaaS solutions
pain_points: Scaling customer success operations as company grows
Maintaining high customer satisfaction during rapid expansion
Implementing AI effectively to solve real customer problems
Managing customer engagement across different segments
Building consistent high-performance culture across teams
Efficient customer onboarding and retention strategies
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-driven email focusing on customer success best practices and AI implementation in SaaS, reference their recent AI launch and customer success leadership role, offer insights on scaling customer success operations, and suggest a brief call to discuss industry trends and challenges in B2B SaaS customer success.
personalization: Mention their recent promotion to VP of Customer Success (May 2024)
Reference GetAccept's AI product launch and their focus on building with intent
Note their long tenure at GetAccept (6+ years) showing company loyalty
Connect with their interest in high-performance culture and scaling challenges
Acknowledge their background in both customer success and marketing automation
Reference their location in Malmö, Sweden for local context

## About

I have over 25 years in the Telecom industry both wireless and wireline. I have worked for carriers, managed the Indirect Sales Channel in Los Angeles for Nextel Communications and then the Central Region for Internet Connect. I have managed North America Agent Partner Sales for EPIC iO (formerly Broad Sky Networks) a nationwide wireless broadband provider offering 4G/5G Managed services for Primary, Backup, Temp Deployment, POTs Replacement, CSD-Wan, Private LTE and AIoT solutions. Currently I manage our Customer Success Team providing exceptional support to our customer base, enhancing solution adoption and growth.  
We are experts at providing the highest quality Business Class Wireless Solutions for Businesses and utilizing the power of AI and IoT to provide the best outcomes for our Clients and Partners. We are providing the solutions for a Smarter, Safer, more Connected World.

Her leadership roles demonstrate decision-making authority for tools and processes. While exact company sizes aren't specified, her work with scaling companies through fractional roles suggests she operates in the target company size range and deals with operational chaos in support/customer success operations.

Company appears to be in growth phase (scale-up) with B2B/SaaS environment. Strong decision-making authority as Head of department with history of managing multi-million euro operations and implementing process improvements.

Balancing efficiency with empathetic customer experience

Team management across multiple locations/subsidiaries
Cost optimization while improving customer satisfaction
Process simplification and standardization

Reference their background in both B2C and B2B customer service

Mention their recent certifications in change management and leadership

Team management and employee satisfaction in remote/hybrid environments
Driving customer adoption and reducing churn rates
Integrating customer feedback into product development cycles
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-driven email focusing on customer success best practices, referencing his role at Connectbase and shared industry challenges. Position your solution as complementary to his customer satisfaction goals. Follow up with a LinkedIn connection request mentioning mutual interests in customer success leadership.
personalization: Reference his VP of Customer Success role at Connectbase specifically
Mention his focus on driving customer and employee satisfaction from his LinkedIn about section
Note his extensive coaching background in youth sports as a leadership parallel
Connect to the Greater Boston area location
Acknowledge his Bryant University education if relevant to your solution

## About

With a proven track record in the technology industry focusing on customer success, I have applied my expertise with a solution-driven mindset, with a passion for understanding clients' needs and delivering innovative solutions to meet those needs.  
I take great pride in my extensive understanding of customer relationship management, utilizing my interpersonal skills and leadership abilities necessary for building and motivating high-performing teams with the aim of driving customer engagement and satisfaction.  
Some of my most celebrated career highlights to date include the following:  
\- Consistent in growing few licenses deal to Enterprise License Agreements  
\- Maintaining a consistent customer retention rate of 96%, showcasing my ability to nurture client relationships.  
\- Surpassing revenue growth targets by an impressive 120%, reflecting my steadfast commitment to driving business expansion and profitability while delivering exceptional value and leadership.  
\- Effectively reducing the average time to value by 35% within eight months, demonstrating innovative strategies and leadership in enhancing customer experiences.  
\- Contributing significantly to company’s revenue through strategic planning and execution across various areas such as delivery, retention, professional services and upselling, showcasing my multifaceted approach to business growth.  
\- Elevating retention rates from 66% to 98% by executing strategic initiatives and overseeing the largest territory within the company, showcasing consistent success and effective team management.  
\- Pioneering the establishment of a new business territory in the Bermuda & Caribbean region, effectively converting leads into new business for the company's product line.  
\- Successfully securing major enterprise contracts with esteemed clients and strengthening the company's presence and reputation in the market.  
\- Driving a remarkable 4x increase in adoption within customer base, demonstrating effective portfolio management and successful rollout processes.  
\- Facilitating over 17 significant partner engagements with leading security partners such as Symantec and McAfee, overseeing global teams and delivering tailored solutions to address customer business challenges.  
My commitment to excellence, dedication to client service, and unwavering work ethic have collectively shaped my professional journey, making me a trusted professional and earning me multiple prestigious awards year after year.  
  
Expertise: Customer Relationship Management (CRM), Customer Experience, Customer Success, Relationship Building

    In today’s fast-paced work environment, we often get caught up in deadlines, deliverables, and the constant push for results. What we sometimes forget is that behind every project and every success story are people — colleagues who show up every day, contribute their best, and keep things moving forward. A few words of recognition can go a long way in making someone feel valued, energized, and motivated to give their best. A Personal Moment That Stuck with Me Not too long ago, I received a short note from the head of another function. It wasn’t long or formal — just a quick acknowledgment: "Hey – I appreciate the work you're doing. Thank you." It was just one line. But it carried weight. That moment reminded me how powerful recognition can be, especially when it comes from someone who isn’t directly tied to your role or your team. It wasn’t about performance reviews, KPIs, or metrics. It was simply a human-to-human appreciation. Why This Matters When we take the time to appreciate our colleagues: We build connection: A simple “thank you” bridges silos and strengthens relationships across teams. We inspire productivity: Recognition fuels motivation, often more than incentives or targets. We create culture: A culture of appreciation makes workplaces not just productive, but joyful. Appreciation doesn’t cost anything, but it creates ripples that can transform how people feel about coming to work every day.

    Reflecting on an Unforgettable Chapter at Seclore ❣️ As I turn the page and say goodbye to my time at Seclore, my heart is full of gratitude and love. These past two years have been an extraordinary journey — filled with incredible experiences, growth, and the privilege of working alongside some of the most amazing, passionate people across the country and the Middle East. I'm truly thankful for the relationships I've built, the lessons I've learned, and the memories that will stay with me forever. The support, camaraderie, and shared purpose have touched me deeply and made this chapter truly special. A special thank you to my CRO and mentor,[Justin Endres](https://sa.linkedin.com/in/justinendres?trk=public_profile__reactions-text)s for entrusting me to spread my love for Seclore all over the country. I am so blessed to call you a friend and confidant! While I’m excited for what’s next, I will always cherish the moments, the challenges, and the people who made this journey so meaningful. Thank you, Seclore, for an unforgettable experience — I will carry it with me always. Wishing the company and my colleagues continued success and growth. Here’s to new beginnings, with a heart full of gratitude.[Sagar Dharman](https://www.linkedin.com/in/sagardharman?trk=public_profile__reactions-text)[Julie Lotze     ### Shripriya Ranade
    
    1w
    
    [Nipun Mohanty liked this](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/shripriya-ranade-8380a824_growth-doesnt-happen-in-the-spotlight-activity-7379823882842734592-ubIs)
    
    Growth doesn’t happen in the spotlight — it happens in the cocoon. 🐛➡️🦋 Anyone else feel like the cocoon phase deserves more airtime? That weird phase where growth is brewing but nothing’s visible yet? After recently wrapping up my adventure at Infosys, I’ve been chewing on why moving on feels like peeling an onion — layered, emotional, and occasionally tear-inducing — even when you know it’s the right recipe for growth. Over the weekend I was giving a thought to my old world. It wasn’t the role or the responsibilities I missed — it was the map I’d memorized. The familiar routes, the landmarks, the version of me who knew exactly where to go and what to search. Now, I’m somewhere new, and the compass is recalibrating. I am in a fog state of mind. Not lost — just somewhere between the familiar and the new. I’m learning to sit with both the uncertainty and the curiosity — like standing in a foggy valley between two mountains. The old peak is behind me, familiar and well-trodden. The new one is just beginning to emerge through the mist. And somewhere in this quiet middle, I can feel the contours of a new beginning forming — not just a new role, but a new Rythm of me. It’s the space where curiosity begins to stretch its legs, questions bubble up, and new possibilities quietly start to surface. It’s that strange, stretchy middle ground — after you’ve let go of the old, but before the new has fully arrived. Like a caterpillar in a cocoon, you’re no longer who you were, but not yet who you’re becoming. Yes, it’s uncomfortable — like standing in a room where the furniture’s been rearranged and you’re not quite sure where to sit. But it’s also where the seeds of change are planted. Because real growth doesn’t happen in the spotlight. It happens in the cocoon. Would be great to hear your thoughts? Have you undergone such transition periods leading to growth?

    Launch day. Battlefield 6 is finally here. It’s hard to capture what it means to see this come to life — not just the game itself, but everything behind it: the collaboration, the scale, and the shared determination across Battlefield Studios and all our partners who made it possible. As Head of Operations, I’ve had the privilege of standing at the crossroads of it all — watching teams from different studios, cultures, and disciplines move in sync toward one vision. That’s where the real magic happened. There were challenges, and there were moments of pure inspiration — moments where you could feel the power of a united team building something extraordinary together. Those are the moments that remind me why I do what I do. I’m incredibly proud of this team — of their ambition, their craft, and their belief in one another. It’s been an honor to help guide that energy toward something this bold. To everyone — our teams, partners, and players — thank you for being part of this journey. We said we’d get there. And we did. See you on the Battlefield.     I think we would all agree, one of the most critical steps to master in the sales process is discovery. But good discovery isn't just about nailing the first conversation, the best discovery happens consistently throughout the entire deal cycle. I often see salespeople get derailed with objection handling. Objections can feel like rejection which puts all of our emotions, doubts and insecurity on high alert for fight or flight. Next time you hear an objection - take a deep breath and respond by first asking a question to gain more insight on the heart of the concern. Shift your perspective and build confidence by knowing - objections are simply an opportunity for deeper discovery. Don't give up, keep digging.

        I specialise in customer relationship management, helping companies and businesses in Eastern Europe achieve their strategic goals through the development of sustainable and productive partnerships.  
          
        How I Can Help Your Business:  
        I manage customer relationships at all project stages, serving as the primary point of contact between the client and the company.  
        I strive to understand your business case deeply and your company's needs to create highly effective and personalised… Show more
        
        I specialise in customer relationship management, helping companies and businesses in Eastern Europe achieve their strategic goals through the development of sustainable and productive partnerships.  
          
        How I Can Help Your Business:  
        I manage customer relationships at all project stages, serving as the primary point of contact between the client and the company.  
        I strive to understand your business case deeply and your company's needs to create highly effective and personalised solutions.  
        I identify potential business opportunities and forward them to the relevant stakeholders for further development.  
          
        My Mission:  
        My primary goal is to ensure that your business and clients interact effectively and harmoniously. I aim to create unique strategies that contribute to strengthening your partnerships and ensuring the sustainable growth of your business.  
          
        My Experience:  
        I have worked successfully in customer relationship management for many years, and my experience spans various industries and companies. I have had the opportunity to collaborate with large corporations, startups, and small businesses, allowing me to develop a deep understanding of different needs and aspects of managing the customer experience.  
          
        My Values:  
        I adhere to principles of honesty, trust, and excellence in customer service. My work is based on a commitment to continuous improvement and innovation to deliver the best results for clients and the company.  
          
        Feel free to reach out to me:  
        If you are interested in collaboration or would like to learn more about how I can assist your business, please do not hesitate to contact me. I am always open to discussing new opportunities and ready to begin working on improving your customer relationships. Show less

name: Olga Guseva
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at Power To Be Found indicates senior decision-making authority over customer support operations. The role inherently involves managing ticket resolution workflows, knowledge retention, and operational efficiency in customer success - directly aligning with ResolveOnce's target pain points of resolution horror, knowledge loss, and ticket bouncing. While specific company size isn't confirmed, the VP title suggests responsibility for scaling support operations in what appears to be a B2B/SaaS environment.

talking_points: Customer success leadership and strategy
Scaling customer success operations
Driving customer retention and expansion
Building high-performing customer success teams
Customer experience optimization
Metrics and KPIs for customer success
Customer onboarding and adoption best practices
pain_points: Customer churn and retention challenges
Scaling customer success with limited resources
Measuring and proving ROI of customer success
Aligning customer success with sales and product teams
Managing customer expectations and escalations
Onboarding and adoption bottlenecks
Customer health monitoring and proactive engagement
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-driven email focused on customer success challenges and opportunities, referencing her VP role and experience. Keep it concise, professional, and focused on how your solution can help her achieve her customer success goals. Follow up with a LinkedIn connection request if no response.
personalization: Reference her VP of Customer Success title specifically
Mention her company Power To Be Found by name
Acknowledge her leadership role in customer success
Connect outreach to common challenges faced by customer success leaders
Use professional tone appropriate for executive-level outreach

name: Ralphie (ralphette) White
classification_reason: VP of Customer Success at Deepgram (B2B/SaaS company likely in the target size range) - this senior leadership role inherently manages customer support operations, handles ticket/resolution workflows, faces knowledge retention challenges with team scaling, and has decision-making authority for operational tools and processes to address the exact pain points described (resolution horror, ticket bouncing, agent efficiency). The VP title confirms strategic influence over customer success operations where these operational chaos issues manifest.

name: Rengasamy Murugesan
classification_reason: Senior Technical Support Manager with 11+ years at IT World Pte Ltd managing support operations, team communication, and process efficiency. Experience includes technical support management, content management systems, team coordination, and operational improvements. Role involves managing various environments, ensuring minimal disruption, and using technology to improve efficiency - directly aligning with ResolveOnce's target of support/IT operations facing ticket resolution, knowledge management, and operational chaos challenges.

talking_points: Customer success leadership and post-sales expertise
Experience driving customer and employee satisfaction
Background in B2B SaaS environment at Connectbase
Strong community involvement in youth sports coaching
Educational background from Bryant University
Extensive professional network with 2K+ followers and 500+ connections
pain_points: Managing customer success metrics and retention in competitive SaaS market
Scaling customer success operations as company grows
Balancing post-sales support with proactive customer engagement
Team management and employee satisfaction in remote/hybrid environments
Driving customer adoption and reducing churn rates
Integrating customer feedback into product development cycles
analysis.outreach_approach: Start with a value-driven email focusing on customer success best practices, referencing his role at Connectbase and shared industry challenges. Position your solution as complementary to his customer satisfaction goals. Follow up with a LinkedIn connection request mentioning mutual interests in customer success leadership.
personalization: Reference his VP of Customer Success role at Connectbase specifically
Mention his focus on driving customer and employee satisfaction from his LinkedIn about section
Note his extensive coaching background in youth sports as a leadership parallel
Connect to the Greater Boston area location
Acknowledge his Bryant University education if relevant to your solution
